steps.text:
This site is home to the original variant of chess called ”Token.” 
  
 Here you can learn the game, analyze custom positions, or play with a friend or a stranger.
This tutorial explains the concept of the game, and contains instructions for using available features.

standard-rules.title: The game of chess...
standard-rules.quote: “The game of chess is a lake in which a mosquito can bathe and an elephant can drown.” – Indian Proverb

steps.text:
Chess is a board game that has been played for roughly half a millenium. 
 To learn the basics of the game, [lichess.org](https://lichess.org/learn) is a great comprehensive source.

In understanding the concept of chess *variants*, it helps to know that chess itself is a European *variation* of a type of board game that has existed for around 1,000 years longer than modern chess. The original game, [Chaturanga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaturanga), spread to other regions and evolved into [Makruk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Makruk), [Shogi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shogi), and many other variations. These variations have different pieces and rules, but share the concept of a coordinate system and a set of movable figures, one of which must be protected. 
 Below is a game of [Xiangqi.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi)

fairy-chess.title: Strange characters...
fairy-chess.quote: “We do these things for ourselves alone.” – Thomas Rayner Dawson, fairy chess composer

steps.text: “Fairy Chess“ is a general term for a chess variant that includes nonstandard piece types, or “fairy pieces.“

Below is a [variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knighted_chess) imagined by third world chess champion José Raúl Capablanca. 
 Note the unorthodox 10x8 board and the addition of two fairy pieces.

It was popular in some historical chess communities to include fairy pieces in chess compositions. 
 The puzzle below was composed in 1911 by [Thomas Rayner Dawson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Rayner_Dawson), a prolific fairy chess composer. 
 It involves a fairy piece which combines the movement of a rook and a knight.
steps.note: White to move, mate in two.

token-chess.title: Token
token-chess.quote: “The ~~pawn~~ token is the soul of chess.” – François-André Danican Philidor

steps.text:
Token adds a unique collection of fairy pieces and a **draft system** to the standard game of chess. 
 Each piece has a set value measured in ”tokens,” and players select their own setup with a budget of 39 tokens.
More information on drafting is detailed in the ”setup” section of this tutorial.

Champion.title: Champion
Champion.quote: “Suffer now and live the rest of your life as a champion.” – Muhammad Ali

steps.text:
The Champion combines the movement of the Rook and Knight pieces. It is a classic addition in chess variants. 
 In Token, it takes the name given by Italian priest [Pietro Carerra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietro_Carrera), who first introduced the *Campione* to western chess in the 17th century.
steps.note: Capture the pawn, then the knight.

steps.text: You can castle with the Champion, just as you would a rook!

Princess.title: Princess
Princess.quote: “Your princess is quite a winning creature. Her appeal is undeniable.” – Count Rugen

steps.text:
The Princess combines the movement of the Bishop and Knight. 
 The combination of short and long range strength makes her exceedingly tricky to play against.
steps.note: White to move, mate in one.

steps.text: As seen in the above example, one advantage of the Princess is her ability to checkmate a cornered king without additional help. Below is a slightly more complex illustration of this idea.
steps.note: Find the checkmate in two. (Difficulty: Medium)

Amazon.title: Amazon
Amazon.quote: “I will not be triumphed over.” – Cleopatra VII

steps.text:
Behold! The all-powerful Queen+Knight hybrid, popularly called the [Amazon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazons) in reference to greek mythology. 
 Impressively, she can checkmate a king on the edge of the board without help from another piece.
steps.note: White to move, mate in one. (Bonus: find both solutions!)

steps.text:
It is nearly impossible to survive more than a few moves against an Amazon in endgame play. 
 In a more advanced example below, the Amazon swiftly overcomes a Champion with a beautiful *zugzwang*.

Mann.title: Mann
Mann.quote: “Every man dies. Not every man really lives.” – William Wallace

steps.text:
A Mann is equivalent to the King, but as he was not born into royalty the game does not hinge on his well-being. 
 Most valuable in endgames, he can deliver checkmate to a king unlike his minor piece counterparts.
steps.note: White to move, mate in two.

steps.text: A Mann is a great protector of the King. The below example demonstrates his ability to hold a draw against a Queen.
steps.note: Use the Mann to block the checks.

Painter.title: Painter
Painter.quote: “I dream my paintings, and then I paint my dreams.” – Vincent van Gogh

steps.text:
While similar to a pawn, a Painter has no violence in their heart. They are a dreamer, but not a fighter. 
 Rather than capture, the Painter *paints* pieces the opposite color.
steps.note: Push the Painter, then paint the rook.

steps.text:
Even when [promoting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Promotion_(chess)), the Painter refuses to pick up a sword. 
 Instead, they become the *Royal Painter*, which moves like a Queen but *paints* instead of capturing.

The Snare does not capture, but instead restricts the movement of opposing pieces **directly next to or in front of it.** 
 In the diagram below, the rooks *cannot* move, but the knights can.

The Snare moves forward one square, straight or diagonally. 
 This example demonstrates the ability of a snare to assist in capturing a valuable target, such as a queen.
steps.note: Ensnare the opposing queen, then attack it with a pawn.

steps.text:
Note that since the Snare cannot capture, it cannot give check. 
 However, a Snare can trap a king, often leading to an easy checkmate!
steps.note: White to move, mate in two.

steps.text:
Like the Painter, the Snare does *not* promote like a pawn. 
 It promotes to a *Rolling Snare,* which can move 2 squares in any direction. Unlike the Snare, it also traps pieces directly *behind* it.
steps.note: White to move, mate in three.

Wizard.title: Wizard
Wizard.quote: “A wizard is never late. Nor is he early. He arrives precisely when he means to.” – Gandalf

steps.text: The Wizard moves up to two squares like a queen. Like a knight, the Wizard can jump over any pieces in the way.
steps.note: Jump over the pawn, then capture the queen.

steps.text:
The Wizard has the ability to swap places with a friendly piece within its movement range. 
 This ability even disregards pins, contrary to standard chess rules which disallow moving “through“ check.
The Wizard may be used to escape the King from dangerous places, including positions that are otherwise checkmate!

Archer.title: Archer
Archer.quote: “Swift as the wind, silent as the forest.” – Sun Tzu

steps.text: The Archer is a slow piece, moving one square diagonally at a time. This makes it a color-bound piece, like the Bishop.
The Archer can capture without moving, given that the captured piece is **2 to 3 diagonal squares away.**
steps.note: Capture the pieces in the following order: Knight, Rook, Pawn

token-values.title: Precious little coins...
token-values.quote: “The ~~pawn~~ token is the soul of chess.” – François-André Danican Philidor

steps.text:
The token is a unit of measurement for a single piece's value in a game. 
 The value is used to determine what is allowed in a starting setup or **draft**, described in the next section. 
 It is equivalent to evaluating pieces in units of pawns. For example, standard chess theory holds that a Knight is worth 3 pawns, a Rook 5 pawns, a Queen 9 pawns, *etc.*

Note that this game is a work in progress, so a piece's evaluation may change in future updates as a measure of balance.

As of **January 2026**, the value in tokens for each piece is as follows:

| Piece | Tokens |
|------|--------|
| Pawn | 1 |
| Knight | 3 |
| Bishop | 3 |
| Rook | 5 |
| Queen | 9 |
| Champion | 8 |
| Princess | 8 |
| Amazon | 13 |
| Mann | 3 |
| Painter | 2 |
| Snare | 2 |
| Wizard | 4 |
| Archer | 7 |

To create a draft, sign up and log in to a Token Chess account. Then click on the 'My Drafts' button in the top right corner. Here you can create and save up to 5 drafts for playing games. Simply drag pieces from the pallette onto the first two ranks of the board-- the first rank is for pieces, the second rank is for pawns, painters, and snares.

**In order to play a multiplayer game, one of your drafts must be set as 'Active' using the button on the drafts page.** 
 This draft, highlighted in green at the top, will be your starting setup when playing a game, and may be changed at any time between games. **Make sure to save any changes made to a draft with the button at the bottom!**

There are special restrictions on the **quantity** of each piece type in a draft. This is designed to keep things fun and fair by promoting diversity and mitigating 'hordes' of a single piece type. For example, while a single Painter is a formidable foe, eight of them together are...*oppressive.*

Just like token values, these quantity restrictions are a work in progress and may change in response to community feedback.

As of **January 2026**, the quantity limit for each piece is as follows:

| Max Allowed | Pieces |
|-------------|--------|
| **1** | Archer, Painter |
| **2** | Amazon, Champion, Princess, Queen |
| **3** | Rook, Wizard |
| **4** | Bishop, Knight, Mann, Snare |

**Please note:** These limits are **per-piece**. For example, you may include *both* a Painter *and* an Archer in the same draft.

Once you have saved and activated at least one draft, you are ready to play a game of Token! At the top menu, click Play -> Game Lobby. Here you can create a game room with a time control of your liking, or join another player's room by clicking their username.

Each room has a code, so you can alternatively join a friend's game by clicking Play -> Join Game and entering their room code. Once in a room, you can rematch as many times as you like, with the option to switch your active draft in between each game of the match.

Multiplayer is currently the **only** supported playing method, as there is no Token Chess AI yet. 
 For fans of computer chess - stay tuned!

**If you or your opponent employs a draft that becomes illegal after balance changes**, the game will start from the default chess position. If this happens, check the balance notes at the bottom of this page, then remove and re-add any pieces in your draft that have increased in value.

Click the 'Board' option at the top menu to use the Board Editor and Analysis feature. Here you can create custom positions by dragging pieces onto the board. You can also copy/edit/paste FEN in the text bar on the bottom. To enter analysis mode, press **Analyze.**
Once in analysis mode, you can freely play moves from both sides. Forward and rewind through moves using the buttons on the side, or with your arrow keys.

Access puzzles by clicking Play -> Puzzles. This feature is a work in progress, as there are only a few haphazard puzzles currently available. In the future, this will host a collection of community-created puzzles of various difficulties.

Token Chess is created and maintained by Nathaniel Clizbe, a software developer and chess enthusiast. 
 Source code for the project is available [here.](https://github.com/cliz1/tokenchess)

This project is developed as an experimental chess platform; bugs and unfinished features may exist. 
 Issues and suggestions are welcome via GitHub.
This platform itself does not yet host any social features. To discuss the game or find opponents, join our [lichess team!](https://lichess.org/team/token-chess-club)
As this game has some novel aspects, it is strongly encouraged to share your experience or suggest ideas!
Token has not received any balance changes since release. When changes occur, details will be posted here.
